awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Functional Analysis of microRNAs in Early Development
awd_abstract_narration:
To understand how a newly fertilized egg becomes a multicellular organism, it is critical to examine how cells within the early embryo integrate various signals to drive development. This research focuses on understanding how cells adopt a specific cell fate as they traverse through the embryo. The cells within the early embryo turn on specific genes, in part, in response to chemical cues they receive from their neighboring cells. This project will discover how genes are controlled by a group of regulatory RNAs. These regulatory RNAs control the level of gene expressions of many genes in several cell types to ensure proper development. Thus, this work contributes to the fundamental understanding of animal development. The project includes education activities that are synergistic to the proposed research project. The first educational activity involves an outreach program at the Delaware Children's Museum where the PI and her students develop a mobile microscope for young children to conduct hands-on, exploratory activities. The second educational activity is to enhance the knowledge base of future early childhood teachers by instilling confidence in science teaching, and by supporting science curriculum development. Inexpensive smartphone microscope platforms are placed in the hands of student teachers to foster future use in their own classrooms. This project is integrated into research training of undergraduate and graduate students and courses taught at the University of Delaware. The proposed educational activities incorporate the PI's expertise in development biology, microscopy, and ongoing research collaborations.
  
MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are highly conserved regulatory RNA molecules that control a myriad of biological processes, including development. In early development, cell specification and pattern formation are controlled by cross-regulation of gene regulatory networks (GRN) and signaling pathways. Signaling morphogen gradients are critical regulators that need to be tightly controlled in order to ensure that the precise organization of the embryo is achieved. This project addresses the overarching hypothesis that miRNAs perform this critical regulatory function. Its goal is to understand how miRNAs integrate GRNs and signaling pathways to drive development. To accomplish this goal, this study uses the sea urchin to study complex developmental processes that are shared by a wide range of organisms. The sea urchin has an exceptionally well-studied GRN and most of its miRNA families consist of a single species, which makes it amenable to unique, powerful functional analysis. To determine the mechanisms by which miRNAs control cell fate specification and directed cell movement during early embryogenesis, the PI will determine regulatory mechanisms of a highly conserved microRNA, miR-31, in the skeletogenic primary mesenchyme cell (PMC) lineage. This project examines how miR-31 coordinately suppresses PMC GRN components and cross-regulates signaling pathways to drive PMC development, using proteomic, transcriptomic, imaging, embryo transplantation, and molecular approaches. Overall, this study will advance the field of miRNA research and contribute to the fundamental understanding of early developmental processes.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Summary

microRNAs (miRNAs) are highly conserved regulatory RNA molecules, that through post-transcriptional suppression of target gene expression, control a myriad of biological processes. Because miRNAs regulate hundreds of genes in an organism, their dysregulation can lead to developmental defects and diseases. The long-term goal of the PI is to understand miRNA-mediated post-transcriptional regulation of signaling pathways controlling various aspects of development. Cell migration in the developing embryo is intimately linked with cell fate specification and differentiation. The PI, and others, found that components of the highly conserved Wnt and growth factor signaling pathways used to control development are regulated by miRNAs. The goal of this project was to determine how miRNAs impact the activation and cross regulation of the Wnt and growth factor signaling pathways in the dynamic environment of an embryo. To accomplish this goal, the sea urchin skeletogenic primary mesenchyme cell (PMC) lineage was used to study miRNA regulation. PMC patterning and differentiation use conserved mechanisms, but the model has the major advantage of having fewer miRNAs and genes represented in gene families compared to vertebrates, which simplifies gene function analyses. Furthermore, large numbers of externally fertilized, synchronous, transparent embryos can be obtained to define cell motility and development. To determine the mechanisms controlling directed cell movement that is often necessary for cell fate specification in all embryos, the PI’s group has revealed how miR-31 regulates specific signaling pathways and specific transcription factors that control how PMCs pattern. Using proteomic, transcriptomic, imaging, and molecular approaches, the PI’s group has identified and validated few targets of miR-31 that encode proteins that remodel cytoskeletal actin. Overall, the results from this study have contributed to our understanding of how miRNAs cross regulate signaling pathways critical for development. A deep understanding of the regulation of a single miRNA will yield new information on the mechanisms of post-transcriptional regulation by other miRNAs, and a major outcome of this work is that it may provide key insights into human conditions resulting from failed control of cell migration during early development, including birth defects and cancer. The PI conducted education activities that are synergistic to the proposed research project that integrated the PI’s expertise in developmental biology and microscopy. The PI’s group participated in educational activity at the Delaware Children’s Museum where the PI and her students developed a mobile microscope for young children to conduct hands-on, exploratory activities. The second educational activity focused on empowering future teachers of STEM education. The PI Song and collaborator Gallo-Fox placed inexpensive smartphone microscope platforms in the hands of student teachers to foster future use in their own classrooms. Further, training of several graduate and undergraduates was support by this project.

Intellectual Merit:

Results from this grant has advanced the field of miRNA research and contributed to the fundamental understanding of early developmental processes. By using a relatively simple invertebrate, the purple sea urchin, the PI elucidated the complicated mechanism in which miRNAs regulate morphogenesis in the context of a developing embryo.

Broader Impacts:

The proposed research discovers how microRNAs regulate developmental processes that are of fundamental significance in animal development. Understanding the functions of specific miRNAs and their targets is essential for improving human health. The proposed research also fostered scientific interest in young children, empowered future early childhood teachers in science instruction, provided mentored research training for undergraduates, and graduate students, and increased general public science literacy in the developmental biology discipline. Under this project, the PI has trained a diverse group of citizens in the STEM fields.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/24/2023
Modified by: Jia L Song
